propositions.text: I met Sophia Lyonnides in Egypt at the end of the war. She held a rather high administrative position in a department of the local consulate.
I first met her at a formal reception.
I soon discovered the efficiency that had earned her that position, though she was still very young (twenty-two at the time).
Besides her good looks, she possessed a clear mind and a serious sense of humor that I found very pleasing.
She was a particularly easy person to talk to, and we had several pleasant meals together and danced occasionally.
That is all I knew of her; until the end of the European War, when I was ordered to the East, that I learned the rest – that I was in love with Sophia and wanted to marry her.
When I discovered this, we were at dinner at the Shepherd's Bush restaurant.
The discovery did not surprise me in the least; it was more like the cognition of a fact I had long been familiar with.
I looked at her with new eyes – but what I saw was what I had long known.
I liked everything I saw.
Her black curly hair, which sprang proudly from her forehead, her bright blue eyes, her small, pugnacious square chin, her straight nose.
I liked the well-cut tailored suit she wore and the white crêpe-de-chine blouse.
She looked so refreshingly English that she stirred in me a violent sense of kinship, a man who had been wandering in foreign parts for three years without seeing his own country.
I do not think that anyone could have been more English than she – and even as I thought this, I suddenly wondered if she was, or could be, as English as she looked.
Was there any such thing in real life as perfection on the stage?
That is all I knew; we talked about our likes and dislikes, about our ideas, about the future, about our friends for the present – Sophia never mentioned her home or her family.
She knew all about me (she was a very good listener), and yet I knew nothing about her.
I presumed she had a normal background, but she never spoke of it.
I did not know her background up to the present.
Sophia asked me what I was thinking about.
I replied truthfully: 'About you.'
'I see,' she said. It sounded as if she really did.
'We may not see each other for some years,' I said.
'I don't know when I shall get back to England.
But when I do, the first thing I shall do will be to come and see you, and to ask you to marry me.'
She listened without blinking.
She sat there, smoking, not looking at me.
For a moment, I was afraid she had not understood.
'Listen,' I said.
'There is one thing that I will never do, and that is to ask you to marry me now.
It wouldn't work.
In the first place, you might refuse me, and I should have to go away sadly, and perhaps to save my vanity, have an affair with some trollop.
If you did not refuse me, what then?
Marriage, and the immediate experience of absence by separation?
Engagement, and a long period of weary waiting?
I couldn't bear that you should do that.
You might meet someone else you liked, and be bound by an engagement, and feel that you had to be 'faithful' to me.
We live in a strange, hurried, everything-hurries world.
Around us, marriage and love affairs, come and go, and are finished with the speed of light.
Better that you should go home, and be free, and look at the new world after the war, and decide what it is you want to get out of this world.
It must be permanent between us, Sophia.
I cannot endure any other kind of marriage.'
'I can't either,' Sophia said.
'On the other hand,' I said, 'I think I have a right to tell you about myself – uh – my feelings.'
'But without any premature lyricism?' Sophia said, in a low voice.
'Darling – don't you understand? I've been trying not to say I love you…'
She stopped me.
'I do understand, Charles. And I like your peculiar way of doing things.
You can come and see me when you get back – if you still want to –'
It was my turn to interrupt her.
'That is not to be doubted.'
'There is always room for doubt, Charles. There are always unpredictable factors.
For instance, you don't know much about me, do you?'
'I don't even know where you live in England.'
'I live at Svenli.'
I nodded.
I knew the well-known London suburb that boasted three first-rate golf courses for its capitalist occupants.
She added, in a meditative voice: 'In a crooked little house…'
I must have shown surprise, for she looked amused and quoted thoughtfully: 'And they all lived in a crooked little house.'
That's us. It's not really a house, you see, but it is crooked – and timbered!
'Is it a large family? Brothers and sisters?'
'A brother, a sister, a mother, a father, an uncle, an aunt, a grandfather, and a great-aunt, and a step-grandmother.'
'Good heavens!' I exclaimed, a little overwhelmed.
She laughed.

'Of course, in normal times, we don't all live together. It was the war and the air raids – but I don't know –' she frowned thoughtfully – 'perhaps mentally, the family has always lived together – under my grandfather's wing.
He's a remarkable man, my grandfather.
He's over eighty, and about four feet ten inches tall, but he makes anyone look like a shadow beside him.'
'He sounds like an interesting character,' I said.
'He is interesting.
He's a Greek from Smyrna. Anastasius Lyonnides.'
She winked and added: 'And very rich.'
'Can anyone be rich after this war?'
'My grandfather will be,' Sophia said confidently.
‘The government’s tricks for exploiting the rich will do nothing to him. He’ll deal with them and make a fortune out of them in the process.’
'I doubt,' she added, 'if you'd like him.'
'And you?' I asked.
'More than anyone in the world,' Sophia said.
It was over two years before I returned to England.
They were not good years.
I wrote to Sophia, and she wrote to me, fairly often.
Her letters, like mine to her, were not love-letters.
They were the letters of intimate friends – talking about personal thoughts and the feelings of everyday life.
Yet I knew that on my side, and I believed on Sophia's side also, our affection had deepened and strengthened.
I arrived in England on a grey September day.
The leaves were shimmering gold in the late afternoon light.
The wind was blowing in gusts.
I had sent Sophia a telegram from the aerodrome.
'Just arrived. Dinner tonight at Mario's at nine. Charles.'
Some hours later, I was sitting reading The Times; scanning the birth, marriage, and death columns, my eye was caught by the name 'Lyonnides':
> The late Anastasius Lyonnides died on September 19th at his home in Svenli, 'Three Gables', aged eighty-five. Brenda Lyonnides, widow.
Followed by another obituary:
> The late Anastasius Lyonnides, died at his home, Three Gables, Svenli, mourned by his son and grandchildren.
I found the two obituaries a little peculiar.
It looked as if the newspaper had made a mistake and published it twice.
But all I could think of was Sophia.
I sent her a second telegram hastily:
'Just seen the news of your grandfather's death. Deepest sympathy. Tell me when I can see you. Charles.'
At six o'clock, I received Sophia's telegram at my father's house:
'Will be at Mario's at nine. Sophia.'
The thought of seeing Sophia again filled me with a mixture of nervousness and excitement.
The next few hours seemed to drag on maddeningly.
I was at Mario's twenty minutes early.
Sophia was only five minutes late.
It is always a shock to see again someone you have not seen for a long time, but who has been in your mind all the while.
When Sophia finally walked through the revolving doors of the restaurant, my feeling was as if our meeting were not real.
She was wearing black, and it struck me as odd!
Most of the other women were also in black, but I thought it was actual mourning – and it surprised me that Sophia would be the sort of person to wear mourning.
Even for a near relative.
We had cocktails – and then went to find a table.
Our conversation was a little fast and eager – asking each other about some friends we had met in Cairo.
It was a manufactured conversation, but it saw us through the initial awkwardness of meeting again.
I offered my condolences on the death of her grandfather, and Sophia said calmly that it had come 'very suddenly'.
Then we went back to old times.
I began to feel uncomfortably that something was wrong – I mean, different from the initial awkwardness that arises naturally from meeting again.
There was something wrong with Sophia herself, distinctly wrong.
Perhaps she was going to tell me she had found someone she liked better?
Tell me that her feelings for me had been 'all a mistake'?
I could not bring myself to think so – I did not know what was wrong.
We continued our polite conversation.
Then, quite suddenly, after the waiter had brought the coffee to the table and bowed himself out, it all came into focus.
Sophia and I sat there, as we had before, at a small table in a restaurant.
The years of separation might as well have not happened.
'Sophia,' I said.
And she said quickly, 'Charles!'
I breathed a great sigh of relief.
'Thank God that's over,' I said.
'What's the matter with us?'
'It's my fault, perhaps. I'm silly.'
'But it's all right now?'
'Yes, it's all right now.'
We smiled at each other.
'Darling!' I said. 'How soon will you marry me?'
Her smile vanished.
The something wrong came back.
'I don't know,' she said.
'Charles, I'm not sure I can marry you.'
'But, Sophia! Why not?
Is it because you find me strange?
Do you need time to get used to me again?
Is there someone else?
No –' I interrupted. 'I'm a fool.
There's nothing of the sort.'
'There is nothing of the sort,' she said, shaking her head.
I waited.
She said, in a low voice: 'It's because my grandfather is dead.'
'Your grandfather is dead? But why?
What difference does that make?
You don't mean – you can't mean – it's a question of money?
He didn't leave any money?
But, of course, my dearest –'
'It's not a question of money,' she said, with a little smile.
'I think you'd be quite willing to marry me if I hadn't a penny to my name. As the saying goes.
And besides, grandfather never lost a penny in his life.'
'Then what is it for?'
'It's just that he's dead – you see, Charles, I don't think he just – died.
I think he may have been – murdered…'
I stared at her, my eyes wide open.
'But – that's too far-fetched. How can you think that?'
'I don't think it's far-fetched.
In the first place, the doctor was queer about it.
He wouldn't sign the death certificate.
They're going to have a post-mortem.
Apparently they suspect something is wrong.'
I didn't argue with her.
Sophia had plenty of brains; any conclusion she arrived at was bound to be reliable.
Instead, I said eagerly: 'Their suspicions may be incorrect.
But that apart, if they are correct, how does that affect you and me?'
'It may affect it in certain circumstances.
You're in the diplomatic service.
They're very particular about the wives and families of diplomatic staff.
No – don't say what you're going to say, I know what you'll say.
You'll say – and I believe you mean it – and theoretically I agree with you.
But I have my pride – a very stubborn pride.
I want our marriage to be something good for everybody – and I don't want you to sacrifice yourself for love!
Besides, as I said, it may be all right…'
'You mean that the doctor – may have been mistaken?'
'Even if he was wrong, it doesn't matter – as long as the right person killed him.'
'What do you mean by that, Sophia?'
'It's beastly to say it.
But still, it's best to be honest after all.'
She went on before I could speak.
'No, Charles, I won't say any more.
Perhaps I've said too much already.
But I was determined to see you tonight – and to see you and to let you understand.
We can't decide anything until this matter is cleared up.'
'At least you can tell me what you have to say.'
She shook her head.
'I don't want to.'
'But – Sophia –'
'No, Charles.
I don't want you to see us from my point of view.
I want you to see us with the impartial eyes of an outsider.'
'Then what am I to do?'
She looked at me, and a strange light flashed in her bright blue eyes.
'You will learn from your father,' she said.
I had told her in Cairo that my father was Assistant Commissioner of the Scotland Yard.
He was still in office.
At her words, a chill ran down my spine.
'Is it as serious as that?'
'I think so.
Do you see that man sitting alone at the table near the door? – a rather handsome, sturdy ex-soldier type?'
'Yes.'
'I saw him on the platform at Svenli when I got on the train this evening.'
'You mean he followed you here?'
'Yes.
I think we are all – what shall I say? – under observation.
They have more or less hinted that we are not to leave the house.
But I was determined to see you.'
Her small square chin jutted out defiantly.
'I climbed down the water-pipe from the bathroom window.'
'Darling!'
'But the police are efficient, and, of course.
There was my telegram to you.
Oh, what the hell – here we are – together…
But from now on, we must act separately.'
She paused, and then added: 'Unfortunately – undeniably – we love each other.'
'Undeniably,' I said. 'But don't call it unfortunate.
We have been through a world war, and we have escaped so many sudden deaths – I don't see why we should be upset by the sudden death of an old man – by the way, how old was he?'
'Eighty-five.'
'Of course.
It said so in The Times.
If you ask me, I should say he died of old age, and any respectable doctor would have accepted the fact.'
'If you had known my grandfather,' Sophia said, 'you would be surprised that he could have died at all!'
I had always had a certain amount of interest in my father's police work, but I had no idea that I should ever have a direct interest in it.
I had not yet seen my father.
He had gone out when I returned, and after my bath and shave and change of clothes, I had gone out to meet Sophia.
But when I got back home, Glover told me he was in the study.
He was sitting at his desk, frowning at a pile of papers.
He sprang from his seat as I entered.
'Charles! What a long time it's been.'
Our reunion after five years of war might have been a great disappointment to the French.
But as a matter of fact, the feeling of reunion was there.
My father and I were very fond of each other, and we understood each other very well.
'I have some whisky here,' he said.
'When did you get back?
Sorry I was out when you arrived.
I've been terribly busy.
Just got a devil of a case.'
I lay back in an armchair, and lit a cigarette.
'Anastasius Lyonnides?' I asked.
His eyebrows shot down.
He glanced at me quickly.
His voice was polite and curt.
'How did you come to say that, Charles?'
'Am I right?'
'How did you know?'
'From information received.'
Father waited for me to continue.
'My information,' I said, 'is from inside.'
'Don't string me along, Charles, tell me.'
'You may not like it,' I said.
'I met Sophia Lyonnides in Cairo.
I fell in love with her.
I intend to marry her.
I met her tonight.
We dined together.'
'Dined together? In London?
I wonder how she managed that?
They were all requested – very politely, of course – to remain at home.
'Yes.
But she climbed out of the bathroom window.'
Father's lips twisted for a moment, then he smiled.
'She appears,' he said, 'to be a young woman of considerable resource.'
'But your men are efficient,' I said.
A man of military appearance followed her to Mario's restaurant.
I suppose I shall appear in his report to you.
Five feet eleven inches, brown hair, brown eyes, wearing a dark blue pinstripe suit, etcetera.'
Father stared at me.
'Are you serious about her?' he asked.
'Yes,' I said. 'I'm serious, Father.'
There was a silence.
'Do you mind?' I asked.
'If it were a week ago – I shouldn't have minded.
Her family is well-to-do – she will inherit property – and I know you.
You don't easily lose your head.
Given that –'
'Given what, Father?'
'Perhaps it doesn't matter, if –'
'If what?'
'If it's the right person who did it.'
That was the second time that evening I had heard that phrase.
My interest was aroused.
'Who is the right person?'
He looked at me sharply.
'How much do you know about this?'
'Nothing.'
'Nothing?'
He seemed surprised.
'Didn't the girl tell you?'
'No…
She said she preferred me to see it from the angle of an outsider.'
'I wonder what for?'
'Isn't it obvious?'
'No, Charles.
I don't think it is.'
He began to pace up and down, his brow furrowed.
The cigar in his hand had gone out.
That showed how much he was disturbed.
'How much do you know about the family?' he asked suddenly.
'Hell, I know the old man and a whole pack of grandchildren, and I haven't the foggiest idea about them.
I paused, then said, 'You've got to make me understand, Father.'
'All right,' he said, and sat down.
'Well – I'll start from the beginning – from Anastasius Lyonnides.
He came to England at the age of twenty-four.'
'A Greek from Smyrna.'
'You do know that much?'
'Yes, but that's all I do know.'
The door opened, and Glover entered to say that Superintendent Tavenner had arrived.
'He's in charge of the case,' my father said.
'We'd better have him in.
He's investigating the family.
He knows more about them than I do.'
I asked if the local police had reported it to the Yard.
'It's in our district.
Svenli is within the Metropolitan area.'
I nodded, and Superintendent Tavenner came in.
I had known Tavenner for some years.
He greeted me warmly and congratulated me on my safe return.
'I'm filling Charles in on the case,' Father said.
'Correct me if I'm wrong, Tavenner.
Lyonides came to London in 1884.
He started a small restaurant in Soho, made money, and opened another.
Soon he owned seven or eight restaurants.
Every one of them made a fortune.'
'He never made a mistake, whatever he did.'
Superintendent Tavenner said.
'He had a natural sixth sense,' Father said.
Eventually he became the backer of most of the well-known restaurants in London.
Then he invested heavily in the catering business.'
'He was also the backer of many other businesses,' Tavenner said.
Second-hand clothes, pawn-shops, and many others.
Of course,' he added thoughtfully, 'he was never honest.'
'You mean he was a crook?' I asked.
Tavenner shook his head.
'No, I don't mean that.
Not quite honest – but not a crook.
Never did anything illegal.
But he was the sort of man who exploited every loophole in the law.
He made a fortune out of this war too, he was so old.
He never did anything illegal – but once he had done something, you had to pass a new law to plug the hole, if you know what I mean.
But by then he had already slipped into another loophole.'
'He doesn't sound very attractive,' I said.
'Strangely enough, he was.
He had character, you know.
You could feel it.
He wasn't much to look at.
Just a short – ugly little man – but attractive – women were always attracted to him.'
'His marriages were rather surprising,' my father said.
'He married the daughter of a country squire – a representative of the yeomanry.'
I raised my eyebrows.
'For money?'
Father shook his head.
'A love match.
She met him when she was catering for a friend's wedding – and fell in love with him.
Her parents strongly disapproved, but she was determined to marry him.
I tell you, the man had charm – a certain powerful exoticism that captivated her, and captured her heart.
She was tired of her own kind.'
'Happy marriage?'
'Very happy, strangely enough.
Of course, their respective friends drifted away (money wasn't everything in those days, couldn't bridge the class gulf), but they didn't seem to care.
They were happy enough without friends.
He built a rather eccentric house in Svenli, and they lived there and had eight children.
'Old Lyonnides chose Svenli wisely.
The district was just beginning to be fashionable then.
The second and third golf courses had not yet been built.
Some of the old resident families there were keen gardeners, and they liked Mrs. Lyonnides, and some rich city men wanted to get into Lyonnides' good books, so they could choose their friends.
They were quite happy, I believe, until she died of pneumonia in 1905.'
'Leaving him with eight children?'
'One died in infancy, and two sons were killed in the war.
One daughter married in Australia and died there.
One unmarried daughter was killed in a motor accident, and another died a year or two ago.
There are only two left alive – the elder son, Roger, married but with no children, and Philip, who married a well-known actress and has three children, your Sophia, Eustace, and Josephine.'
'They all live together in – what do you call it? – 'Three Gables?'
'Yes.
Roger Lyonnides' family has been living there since their house was bombed early in the war.
Philip's family has been there since 1938.
And an elderly aunt, Miss Haviland, a sister of the first Mrs. Lyonnides.
She always openly disapproved of her brother-in-law, but after her sister's death, she felt it was her duty to accept her brother-in-law's invitation to live with him and look after the children.'
'She's a woman who believes in personal obligation,' Superintendent Tavenner said.
'But she's not the sort of person to change her opinion of anyone.
She always disapproved of Lyonnides' methods –'
'Oh,' I said, 'it sounds like a large family.
Who do you think killed him?'
Tavenner shook his head.
'It's too early,' he said, 'to say.'
'Come off it, Tavenner,' I said.
'I think you have a pretty good idea in your mind who did it.
We're not in court, old man.'
'That's true,' Tavenner said gloomily.
'And we may never get the case into court.
'You mean he wasn't murdered?'
'Oh, he was murdered, alright, poisoned.
But you know what these poisoning cases are like.
It's devilishly hard to get evidence, and very confusing.
Everything might point one way –'
'That's what I want to know.
You have a strong idea in your mind, haven't you?'
'It's a very strong probability case.
What I have in mind is one of the obvious possibilities.
A perfectly planned thing.
But I really don't know.
It's too cunning.'
I looked pleadingly at my father.
He said slowly:
'As you know, Charles, in murder cases, the obvious possibility is generally the right one.
Old Lyonnides married again, ten years ago.'
'At seventy-five?'
'Yes.
He married a young woman of twenty-four.'
I whistled.
'What sort of young woman?'
'A girl from a tea shop.
A very high-minded young woman – pale and cold and beautiful.'
'She is your obvious possibility?'
'That's what I should ask you, sir,' Tavenner said.
'She's only thirty now – a dangerous age.
She likes comfort.
And there's a young man in the house.
The tutor for the grandchildren.
Didn't go to the war – bad heart or something.
They are very fond of each other.'
I looked at him thoughtfully.
It was, of course, a stock story.
Entanglement.
And my father had emphasized that this second Mrs. Lyonnides was a woman of very high-minded principles.
Many murders are committed under such a guise.
'What was the cause of death?' I asked.
'Arsenic?'
'No, we haven't had the analysis back yet – but the doctor thinks it was 'Eserine'.'
'That's a little curious, isn't it?
Of course, it's easily traceable, the purchase.'
'Not so.
It was his own, you know.
Eye-drops.'
'Lyonnides was a diabetic,' my father said.
'He had to inject himself regularly with insulin.
Insulin is kept in small bottles with rubber caps.
The medicine is drawn up with a needle through the rubber cap.
I guessed what he was going to say next.
'So that what was drawn up was not insulin.
But Eserine?'
'Precisely.'
'So who gave him the injection?' I asked.
'His wife.'
I knew now what Sophia meant by the 'right person'.
I asked: 'How did the family get on with the second Mrs. Lyonnides?'
'Not well.
I should say they hardly spoke to each other.
It seemed increasingly clear.
And yet, Tavenner was evidently not satisfied.
'What is suspicious about it?' I asked him.
'Mr. Charles, if it was she, she could have easily replaced the bottle with a real insulin afterwards.
In fact, if it was she, I can't imagine why she didn't.'
'Yes, that seems obvious.
Was there plenty of insulin in the house?'
'Oh, yes.
Plenty of unused and empty bottles.
And if it was she, the doctor would most likely not have noticed anything.
People who die of Eserine poisoning seldom show any external signs.
But because he examined the insulin (to see if the strength was wrong or something), he quickly found out, of course, that it wasn't insulin.'
'Therefore,' I said thoughtfully, 'Mrs. Lyonnides was either very stupid – or possibly very clever.'
'You mean –'
'She might have counted on you thinking that nobody could be so foolish.
What about the others?
Are there any other – suspects?'
Father said calmly:
'Actually, anyone in the house could have done it.
There was always a fair amount of insulin kept in the house – enough for a fortnight, at least.
One of the small bottles might have been tampered with, and then replaced, knowing that it would be used in due course.'
'And anyone could have had access to those bottles, more or less?'
'They weren't locked up.
They were on the bathroom shelf in his part of the house.
Anyone in the house could come and go.'
'Was there any strong motive?'
Father sighed.
'My dear Charles, Anastasius Lyonnides was a very rich man!
It's true he had given a lot of money to his family, but there might be someone who wanted more.'
'But wanting more is the present widow. Is her young man wealthy?'
'No.
Dead broke.'
Something flashed in my mind.
I thought of the nursery rhyme Sophia had quoted.
I remembered the whole rhyme suddenly:
> There was a crooked man and he walked a crooked mile
> He found a crooked sixpence beside a crooked stile
> He bought a crooked cat, which caught a crooked mouse
> And they all lived together in a crooked little house.
I said to Tavenner: 'How did Mrs. Lyonnides attract your attention – the second one? What do you think of her?'
He answered slowly: 'It's hard to say – very hard to say.
She's not easy to get to know.
Very quiet – so you don't know what she's thinking.
But she likes comfort – I'll swear to that.
You know, she reminds me of a cat, a pampered lazy cat…
It's not that I have anything against cats.
Cats are all right…'
He gave a sigh.
'What we need,' he said, 'is evidence.'
Yes, I thought, we all need evidence that Mrs. Lyonnides poisoned her husband.
Sophia needs it, I need it, and Superintendent Tavenner needs it.
Then everything will be all right!
But Sophia isn't sure, and I'm not sure, and I don't think Superintendent Tavenner is sure…
The next day, I went to 'Three Gables' with Tavenner.
My position was peculiar.
Untraditional, to say the least of it.
But my father never did things in a conventional way.
I had a certain connection.
Early in the war, I had worked with the Special Branch of the Scotland Yard.
It was, of course, a totally different matter – but my early efforts gave me some official standing, so to speak.
My father said:
'If we are to solve this case, we must get inside information.
We must understand everybody in that house.
We must understand them from the inside – not from the outside.
You are the person who can get us inside information.'
I did not like this at all.
I threw my cigarette into the fireplace and said: 'Am I a spy for the police? Is that it?
To go and extract inside information from Sophia, whom I love and who loves and trusts me (or so I believe)?'
Father began to look quite indignant.
He said sternly: 'For God's sake, don't take such a vulgar view.
If nothing else, you don't suppose your young woman murdered her grandfather?'
'Of course not.
That's absurd.'
'Well – we don't either.
She was away for some years, and she got on very well with him.
She had a very considerable income, and I might say, he would have been delighted to hear of her engagement to you, and would perhaps have made her a generous dowry.
We don't suspect her.
Why should we?
But one thing you can be quite sure of, if this matter isn't cleared up, the girl won't marry you.
From what you've told me, I'm pretty certain of that.
And remember my words, this is a case that may never be cleared up.
We can reasonably suspect the wife and her young man may have conspired – but to prove it is another matter.
Even now, the case won't go to the Director of Public Prosecutions.
Unless we find definite evidence against her, it will always remain in doubt.
You understand that, don't you?'
Yes, I understood.
Father said calmly:
'Why not talk to her straight?
'You mean – ask Sophia if I –'
I stopped.
'Yes, yes…
I'm not suggesting you go behind the girl's back and do what you want without telling her what you're doing.
Talk to her, and see what she says?'
So the next day I drove to Svenli with Superintendent Tavenner and Inspector Lamb.
A little past the golf course, our car turned into a drive that, I imagined, must have been guarded by two large iron gates before the war.
The gates had been donated to the war effort or requisitioned out of patriotic fervor.
We drove along a curving drive flanked by heather, to the gravel sweep in front of the house.
It was incredible!
I wondered why the house was called 'Three Gables.'
'Eleven Gables' would have been more appropriate!
Strangely, it had a peculiar twist to it – I think I know why.
It was actually a country villa type of building; a country villa out of proportion.
It was as if a country villa had been seen through a giant magnifying glass.
The crooked timbers, the timber-framing, the gables – a crooked little house like a mushroom in the moonlight!
And yet, I thought.
It was the idea of a Greek restaurateur of an English country house.
It had been built deliberately as an Englishman's home – built like a castle!
I don't know what the first Mrs. Lyonnides thought of it.
I don't think he consulted her or told her about the building plans.
It was probably a little surprise for her from her foreign husband.
I don't know whether she was horrified or smiled at it.
She appeared to have lived quite happily in the house.
'It's a bit overwhelming, isn't it?' Superintendent Tavenner said.
'Of course the old gentleman had great ideas for it – built it in three separate houses, as it were, each with its own kitchen etcetera.
Inside everything was of the best, and fitted up like a luxury hotel.'
Sophia came out of the front door.
She wore no hat, and a green shirt and a tweed skirt.
She saw me and stopped dead.
'You?' she cried.
I said: 'Sophia, I have to talk to you.
Where can we go to talk comfortably?'
For a moment, I thought she was going to object, then she turned and said: 'This way.'
We crossed the lawn.
From there you could see the first golf course of Svenli – then a small pine-covered hill, and beyond that a hazy, smoke-filled countryside.
Sophia led me to a rock garden, somewhat neglected, and a rather uncomfortable-looking wooden bench, on which we sat.
'Well?' she said.
Her tone was not encouraging.
I told her – everything.
She listened very intently.
Her face revealed very little of what she was thinking, but when I had finished and stopped, she sighed.
A deep sigh.
'Your father,' she said, 'is a very clever man.'
'My father has his reasons.
I myself think it's a despicable idea – but –'
'Oh, no,' she said.
'It's not despicable at all.
It's the only way that anything good can come of it.
Your father knows what I have in my mind, Charles.
He understands me better than you do.'
She suddenly clenched her fist as if in despair, and struck her other hand with it.
'I have to find out the truth.
I have to know.'
'For us? But, my dearest –'
'Not only for us, Charles.
I have to know it for my own peace of mind.
You know, Charles, I didn't tell you last night – but the fact is – I'm frightened.'
'Frightened?'
'Yes – frightened – frightened – that the police, that your father, that everyone – thinks it's Brenda.'
'The probability –'
'Oh, yes, it's highly possible.
It's possible.
But when I say to myself, 'Perhaps it was Brenda,' I know quite well it's only wishful thinking.
Because, you know, I don't really think so.'
'You don't think so?' I said slowly.
'I don't know.
You've heard everything from an outsider's point of view, as I wanted.
Now I'll let you see it from the point of view of an insider.
I don't feel Brenda is that sort of person at all – she's not the sort of person, I think, who would do anything that would get her into danger.
She values herself too much.'
'And the young man? Lawrence Brown.'
'Lawrence is a coward, through and through.
He wouldn't have the nerve.'
'I suspect.
We don't really know, do we?
I mean, people can surprise you, can't they?
A person is thought to be one way, and sometimes that thought is entirely wrong.
Not always wrong – but sometimes.
But anyhow, Brenda –' she shook her head – 'she's always been regular.
She's what I call a home-girl type.
Likes to sit down and eat sweets, and wear good clothes, and jewels, and read cheap novels, and go to the pictures.
It's a funny thing when you think he was an eighty-five-year-old man, but I really think she was a little afraid of her grandfather.
He was a man of power, you know.
I think he made Brenda feel like she was a romantic woman of thrilling experiences!
He always had a way with women – and that sort of thing is an art – you don't lose the knack, however old you are.'
I put the question of Brenda aside for the moment, and went back to a remark Sophia had made that had troubled me.
'Why did you say,' I asked, 'that you were frightened?'
Sophia shivered a little, and clasped her hands tightly together.
'Because it's true,' she said in a low voice.
It's terribly important, Charles, that I should make you understand this.
You know, we're a very peculiar family…
We all have a good deal of coldness in us – and – different sorts of coldness.
That's the confusing part, the different sorts.
She must have seen my puzzled expression.
She went on, energetically:
'I'll try and make myself clear.
Take grandfather.
He once mentioned casually, when he was telling us about his boyhood in Smyrna, that he had killed two men.
It was over some quarrel – some great insult – I don't know – but it was just something that happened quite naturally.
He forgot about it afterwards.
But in England, to hear anyone say that so casually, it's peculiar.'
I nodded.
'That's one sort of coldness,' Sophia continued.
Then there's my grandmother.
I have very faint memories of her, but I've heard people talk about her.
I think she may have had that sort of coldness that comes from lack of imagination or something.
All those fox-hunting ancestors – and those old generals, that bloodthirsty type.
Full of integrity and arrogance, and not afraid of taking on the responsibility of life and death.
'Isn't that a bit far-fetched?'
'Perhaps it is – but I've always been a little afraid of that type.
Full of integrity, but cold-hearted and cruel.
Then there's my mother – she was an actress – she was a darling, but she had no balance.
She was one of those unconsciously self-centred people who only see things from the point of view of their effect on them.
That's sometimes a little terrifying, you know.
And there's Mrs. Roger Lyonnides, my Uncle Roger's wife.
She's a scientist – doing some sort of important research – and also that sort of cold, bloodless, impersonal type.
Uncle Roger is the opposite – he's the kindest, sweetest man in the world, but he has a frightful temper.
Anything that gets him worked up, and he's almost unconscious of what he's doing.
And there's Father –'
She paused for a long time.
'Father,' she said slowly, 'is almost too controlled.
You never know what he's thinking.
He never shows any emotion.
Perhaps it's an unconscious defence against Mother's over-emotionalism, but sometimes – it worries me a bit.'
'My dear girl,' I said, 'you don't need to torture yourself like this.
In the end, everyone could have murdered him.'
'I think that's true.
Even me.'
'Not you!'
'Oh, Charles, you can't exclude me.
I think I might have killed him…'
She was silent for a moment, then added: 'But if I did, it must have been for something really worth while!'
I laughed.
I couldn't help it.
Sophia smiled faintly.
'Perhaps I am a fool,' she said, 'but we must find out the truth about grandfather's death.
We must find it out.
I wish it was Brenda…'
I felt suddenly sorry for Brenda Lyonnides.
A tall figure was walking with energetic steps along the path leading to us, wearing an old felt hat, a crumpled skirt, and a rather voluminous knitted jumper.
'Aunt Edith,' Sophia said.
The figure stopped once or twice to examine a flowerbed, and then continued towards us.
I got to my feet.
'This is Charles Heyward, Aunt Edith.
My aunt, Miss Haviland.'
Edith Haviland was a woman of about seventy.
She had a shock of untidy grey hair, a weathered face, and shrewd, intelligent eyes.
'Hello,' she said.
'I've heard of you.
Back from the East.
How's your father?'
I was surprised, and replied that he was well.
'I've known him since he was a boy,' Miss Haviland said.
His mother and I were great friends.
You look a bit like her.
Are you here to help us – or for something else?'
'I hope to be of some help,' I said, a little awkwardly.
She nodded.
'We need some help.
There are police everywhere.
Popping up suddenly, all over the place.
Some of them I don't like.
Boys who have been to secondary school shouldn't be police.
Saw Mona Kinno's child directing the traffic the other day.
Don't know what to say about it!
She turned to Sophia: 'Lanie is looking for you, Sophia.
She wants you to ring up for fish.'
'Thank you for the trouble,' Sophia said.
I'll ring up for it.
She darted towards the house.
Miss Haviland turned and walked slowly in the same direction.
I followed her.
'I don't know what we should do without Lanie,' Miss Haviland said.
Almost every house has someone like Lanie.
They come and do the washing and cooking and housework.
Loyal.
I picked her myself – years ago.'
She bent down and fiercely pulled up a tangle of green weed.
'Damn things – bindweed!
The worst weed!
Twists and smothers the flowers – and you can't get rid of them properly, they spread and root underground.'
She threw the bunch of green stuff on the ground savagely and stamped on it with her heel.
'It's a nasty business, Charles Heyward,' she said.
She looked towards the house.
'What do the police think? I suppose I shouldn't ask you.
It seems queer to think of Anastasius being poisoned.
As for that, it seems queer that he's dead at all.
I never liked him – never!
But I'm not used to the idea of him being dead…
Makes the house feel so – empty.'
I said nothing.
From the tone of her voice, Edith Haviland seemed to be in a reminiscent mood.
'I was thinking this morning – I've lived here a long time.
Over forty years.
I came here when my sister died.
He asked me to.
Seven children – the youngest only a year old…
Could I see them brought up by a Latin woman, could I?
An unspeakable marriage, of course.
I always felt Marcia must have been – well – bewitched.
Ugly, vulgar, little foreigner!
He didn't interfere with me – to do him justice.
Nannies, governesses, schools, all chosen and engaged and appointed by me, and the right wholesome nursery food – not that odd rice he used to eat.'
'And you've lived here ever since?' I murmured.
'Yes.
It's a bit strange…
I think I might have left, when the children had all grown up, and married, and got married themselves…
I think I became interested in the garden, really.
Then Philip came.
If a man marries an actress, he can't have any home life.
I don't know why actresses have children.
As soon as they're born, they're whisked away, to go on the stage in Edinburgh or somewhere.
Philip did a sensible thing – he brought his books and himself here.'
'What does Philip Lyonnides do?' I asked.
'He writes books.
Can't think why.
Nobody wants to read them.
They're all about obscure historical details.
Things you've never heard of?'
I admitted.
'He's too rich, that's why,' Miss Haviland said.
Most people have to make money to live, and he doesn't have to.
'His books don't make money?'
'Of course not.
He's said to be a great authority on a certain period of history.
But he doesn't need to make money by writing books – Anastasius gave him about £100,000 – a stupendous sum!
To get round estate duty!
Anastasius made them all financially independent.
Roger runs the catering business – Sophia has a very substantial allowance.
The children's money is in trust.'

concepts.name: Sophia Lyonnides
concepts.context: The main female character, met by the narrator in Egypt. She is young, efficient, intelligent, and possesses a serious sense of humor. The narrator falls in love with her and wants to marry her, but she is hesitant due to her grandfather's recent death and the suspicious circumstances surrounding it.

concepts.name: Narrator (Charles Heyward)
concepts.context: The male protagonist and narrator of the story. He meets Sophia in Egypt, falls in love with her, and plans to marry her. He is a member of the diplomatic service. His father is Assistant Commissioner of Scotland Yard.

concepts.name: Anastasius Lyonnides
concepts.context: Sophia's grandfather, a wealthy Greek from Smyrna who built a fortune in the restaurant and catering business in London. He is described as charming, eccentric, and cunning, but not entirely honest. He died recently under suspicious circumstances, believed to be poisoned.

concepts.name: Grandfather (Anastasius Lyonnides)
concepts.context: Same as Anastasius Lyonnides. Sophia deeply respects and is somewhat afraid of him. His death is the central mystery driving Sophia's hesitation to marry.

concepts.name: Father (Narrator's)
concepts.context: Assistant Commissioner of Scotland Yard. He is a pragmatic and experienced detective who is investigating the death of Anastasius Lyonnides. He is the narrator's father and offers him advice and insights into the case.

concepts.name: Death
concepts.context: The death of Anastasius Lyonnides is the central event. The circumstances are suspicious, believed to be poisoning, and the investigation into it is paramount to the plot.

concepts.name: Murder
concepts.context: The suspicion that Anastasius Lyonnides was murdered is the driving force behind the investigation and Sophia's anxieties. The difficulty in proving it is also a key theme.

concepts.name: Family
concepts.context: The Lyonnides family is large and complex, with various members and their relationships playing a role in the narrative. Their "peculiar" and sometimes "cold" natures are discussed.

concepts.name: House
concepts.context: 'Three Gables' is the Lyonnides family home in Svenli. It is described as large, eccentric, and a bit of a 'crooked little house'.

concepts.name: Police
concepts.context: The police, represented by Superintendent Tavenner and Inspector Lamb, are investigating the death of Anastasius Lyonnides. The narrator's father is also a high-ranking police official.

concepts.name: Motive
concepts.context: The potential motives for the murder of Anastasius Lyonnides are explored, including greed and personal vendettas.

concepts.name: Evidence
concepts.context: The lack of concrete evidence to prove the murder of Anastasius Lyonnides is a major obstacle, preventing the case from going to court.

concepts.name: London
concepts.context: The primary setting for the unfolding events after the narrator's return from Egypt.

concepts.name: Egypt
concepts.context: Where the narrator met Sophia at the end of the war.

concepts.name: War
concepts.context: The backdrop against which the initial meeting and subsequent events take place.

concepts.name: Brenda Lyonnides
concepts.context: The second wife of Anastasius Lyonnides, a young, pale, cold, and beautiful woman. She is a primary suspect in the murder, but her guilt is not definitively proven.

concepts.name: Tavenner
concepts.context: Superintendent Tavenner, who is in charge of the Lyonnides case and works with the narrator's father.

concepts.name: Svenli
concepts.context: The London suburb where the Lyonnides family lives in 'Three Gables'.

concepts.name: Love
concepts.context: The narrator's love for Sophia is a driving force in the narrative, leading him to become involved in the investigation.

concepts.name: Marriage
concepts.context: The narrator's desire to marry Sophia is contingent on the resolution of the mystery surrounding her grandfather's death.

concepts.name: Money
concepts.context: The wealth of Anastasius Lyonnides is a potential motive for his murder.

concepts.name: Poisoning
concepts.context: The suspected method of Anastasius Lyonnides' death.

concepts.name: Character
concepts.context: The diverse and often complex characters of the Lyonnides family are explored, particularly their 'coldness'.

concepts.name: Investigation
concepts.context: The process of uncovering the truth behind Anastasius Lyonnides' death.

concepts.name: Old age
concepts.context: Anastasius Lyonnides was eighty-five when he died, leading some to believe he died of natural causes.

concepts.name: Doctors
concepts.context: The doctor's suspicion that something was wrong with Anastasius Lyonnides' death certificate was crucial.

concepts.name: Insulin
concepts.context: Anastasius Lyonnides' medication, which was potentially substituted with poison.

concepts.name: Eserine
concepts.context: The suspected poison used to kill Anastasius Lyonnides, disguised as eye-drops.

concepts.name: Motive for murder
concepts.context: Exploration of who might have wanted Anastasius Lyonnides dead and why.

concepts.name: The crooked house rhyme
concepts.context: A nursery rhyme that Sophia quotes and that resonates with the eccentric nature of the Lyonnides family and their home.

concepts.name: Miss Haviland
concepts.context: Edith Haviland, Sophia's great-aunt, who has lived with the family for over forty years and expresses her strong opinions about them.

concepts.name: Spy
concepts.context: The narrator's apprehension about acting as a spy for the police among Sophia's family.

concepts.name: Psychological analysis
concepts.context: Sophia's detailed analysis of the different types of 'coldness' within her family.

hierarchy.structure: The document is structured chronologically, beginning with the narrator's past relationship with Sophia and then focusing on the present events following the death of her grandfather. It moves from personal reflection to a detailed police investigation, incorporating character analysis and plot development. The narrative is divided into five sections, each exploring different aspects of the story.
